There is a lot of female nudity including full frontal and topless.  I've been able to watch movies with occasional sex scenes, but this is bothering me so much it hurts.  My SO is very interested in the show and the plot. All I can feel is that I'm not a whole woman.  If I bring up my feelings, he'll be upset and stop watching the show because of me.  How do I get over this? Posts.Title: mammo yesterday-back in for more pix-no results til next week amontro jennyboog

Posts.Content: amontro wrote: I had this posted on Stage IV, but I think Stage III guys seem to respond more timely:  I'm very, very concerned (crying concerned).  Three years ago, had a one-sided mx with mets in my lungs and spine.  After my mammo yesterday (Thursday), I waited in my johnny coat for them to tell me it was ok to get dressed.  Instead I was called in to take another picture with a different angle.  My nurse navigator was on vacation and I had nowhere to go for comfort.  I called my MS's office to find out when the results would come in the the girl said not for a few days and the doctor is not in tomorrow (Friday). Then I thought of you guys, my support group.  Am I being overly worried, or do I have a better chance of mets to spread to my "good" breast before anywhere else? If they catch a cancer, it'll be early and I may not lose the other breast, but I dread a change in treatment or having radiation again.  Any good word? Are they being Dx 9/2008, Stage IV, Grade 3, mets, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: mammo yesterday-back in for more pix-no results til next week amontro jennyboog

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2014 09:44PM amontro wrote: raro - Sometimes the full price of medication is not as expensive as we think. When I thought (and I was wrong) my medical insurance would not pay for an increase of percocet, I asked my pharmacy how much it would cost me out of pocket without going through medical insurance. The price was manageable. Some pharmacies that know what you're going through will go over the costs of meds with you and work something out. Otherwise, you can also try aspirin which is one of the all time best meds, if you can tolerate it.  I have no use for tylenol, ibuprofen, advil, etc., and they're bad for the kidneys/liver. Also, it's ok to feel sorry for yourself. Have a pity party with us on this thread. we're really the only ones who know what you're going through. I've just given you my two cents for free.
Posts.Title: #$@!#!! raro

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2014 08:38AM amontro wrote: Every once in a while I go to seminars "Look Good Feel Better" at my local cancer care hospital. When the discussion was on wigs, the moderator suggested that we should not shave our heads and leave what little hair we have on our head when we are opting for wigs.  I can't remember the reasoning for it, but it sounded good. I haven't had my hair fall out so far, but my wigs have been in a box under my bed for 5 years.

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2014 01:21PM amontro wrote: I'm not sure what AC is.  For nausea, I take zofran with no side effects. I take ativan at night, because I work during the day. As I've mentioned on posts before, percocet makes me clear headed and I can make it though the day. I try not to take it at night because I don't want to be too dependent on it. Therapy is another good suggestion. Ask your onc who they recommend.

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2012 01:38PM amontro wrote: What a coincidence.  I came online today to start a post about having Stage IV and holding my own after 3 1/2 yrs of it, and feeling guilty because others did not have the same amount of time.  Before I came on this topic, I read some othertopics which made me want to cry because of the emotional and physical pain they are going through. My original thoughts were that,when I start going downhill, I would feel worse emotionally because I'll know the end may be near.   Right now, I'm enjoying life as much as I can, at my old age, still working full time, and making my money stretch. Now I know why my oncologist urges me to go do things and take vacations when and if I can physically and financially.  It's scary. My thoughts and prayers are with those we have lost and I also don't understand why.

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2013 01:21PM amontro wrote: I have a love/hate relationship with this forum.  I hate when I read what you all are going through.  I hate that young women with families are tortured about their futures. I hate when beautiful people pass.  But I love the part where I can come and read stories similar to my pain and know that I can make it through just another day.  I love when I have concerns and you are all there with saying just the right thing, and sometimes even having the answers. Thank God for all of you wonderful women.
Posts.Title: How do you get the emotional stamina to stay on the forum? AnacortesGirl ThereseD

Posts.Content: Jun 16, 2015 01:14PM amontro wrote: Conundrum:  Before I came down with Stage IV from the very start, I never took any kind of medication, even over-the-counter meds. that being said, I used to take 2 regular aspirin at least once a day.  I don't know why I chose to do this because I was a health nut.  Anyway, I had been taking aspirin for at least 20 year before dx, and I'm still doing so and my cancer has not advanced in all these 6 1/2 years. So, I didn't ward off cancer, but I haven't gotten worse either.
Posts.Title: Aspirin Against Breast Cancer Bestbird DivineMrsM

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2013 01:34PM amontro wrote: After over 30 years of working out like a gerbil and eating like a rabbit, at my age U Stage IV, I'm eating what I damn well please.  Before bc, I never ate ice cream, candy, processed food, etc. Since I still have to work, I'm indulging myself with the nono's from yesterday and I don't exercise anymore. Fitztwins, unfortunately I can no longer drink wine. It just doesn't taste right to me. Maybe it's a good thing. I'd probably be looped all the time.
Posts.Title: Dairy Foods & Metastic BC Marybetz amontro

Posts.Content: May 14, 2014 01:30PM amontro wrote: Thanks for giving me a chance to rant (a little).  I don't feel like it's a battle.  I don't fight.  I just keep my appointments and take my meds.  I am not a survivor because I have the last phase of breast cancer, and then I'm dead. I won't be surviving anything.    I don't like being told that I'm strong. I'm just rolling with the punches, just as some of you have mentioned.   I also cringe at "how wonderful you look". It's all I can do to put on make up and dye my hair. If you saw me without these cosmetic touches, you'd cringe too.
Posts.Title: Just wondering about the words of battle Boo123 riverhorse

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2013 01:50PM amontro wrote: Most doctors and oncs will let us have as many percs as we need. I only need 3 percs a day.  Then, I told my onc that I take my ativan at night to sleep. Three 0.5 mgs and she flipped "Not all at once!?" No, one every hour just before bedtime.  I had asked for another type of anit anxiety or med to make me calmer and she said it would be too much. I was able to get ambien, but it didn't work. I also have gastro problems since I was born. Since my dx and cancer drugs and treatments, my gastro is more aggravated.  Taking meds to calm my gastro tract is a big deal as well. I can't tell you how great it is to have less pain (percs) and no gastro discomfort. It's a day/night in heaven. Also, I don't dare ask my pcp  for anything. He thinks it's all too much medication. I work full time, so I don't want to be in a stupor when I wake up and throughout the day, so I'm not going to OD. I'm careful with how I take my meds. Why can't we get the  meds we need to help us?  Why is it such a big deal?  It's not like we'll turn into addicts; we'll be dead by then (sorry).

I'll just bite the bullet and tell him "Sorry, no".

Posts.Title: Why do I still have hair? BaseballFan BaseballFan

Posts.Content: amontro wrote: I get my herceptin triple treatment every 3 weeks and an added zometa every six weeks. As time goes on, I believe I've become more sensitive to them. I feel awful for a few days afterwards, so I have taken Benadryl and drink lots of water.  It doesn't help. The reactions are getting worse as time goes by.  NOW, when I'm sent to get a CTscan or MRI, I feel worse than I used to in the past.  Since I've been feeling very dizzy and losing my balance this summer, I was sent for a brain MRI last Saturday and I became even more dizzy and off-balance for 2-3 days.  My head felt muddled and I just felt awful.  The MRI showed no brain cancer, but I need to know what I can do to ask about changing the contrast or take something ahead of time. This reminds me of my surgeries in the past few years. In the hospital when they ask for allergies, I mention that I'm allergic to soy, and they have to change the anesthesia because it contains soy! Getting back to my original symptoms, I think I have a sinus allergy which causes the dizziness. My nose isn't stuffy, but there's pressure over the bridge of my nose.  When I take mucinex, I get some relief.   Is this the right forum to post my concern?  What kind of doctor should I see to about my sensitivities/allergies?  Most specialists have no idea what I'm talking about. Dx 9/2008, Stage IV, Grade 3, mets, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Worse sensitivity to contrasts,herceptin,zometa-help! amontro amontro

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2014 01:43PM amontro wrote: I don't think we can prevent cancer because we don't know what causes it. I was a health nut with food and exercise.  When going to an ob-gyn, all my answers to the breast cancer quiz (breast feeding, ages when having children, non smoking, etc) were on the positive side.  But I got it and Stage IV to start with! Since 6 tears ago, I haven't given a rat's a$$ about what I eat or what I do and I haven't progressed.  Go figure.

Posts.Title: Oxycodone with no constipation! Latte hopeinfitcher

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2014 08:59PM amontro wrote: Years ago, before cancer, and I was a health nut with supplements and  I never needed prescriptions. I used to come home from work take melatonin on an empty stomach.and lie on the sofa watching tv for about an hour.  Then, I'd eat a healthy dinner, relax again before I went to bed and I'd sleep very well.  The secret for me was no activity except eating when I came home and after dinner. After cancer, ambien did not work, some ativan did. Although I felt that percocet made me alert during the day, I found that it helps me sleep if I take one before bedtime.  I wake up ok ready to go to work (no retirement for me, unfortunately). Just my two cents.

I was going to ask "Do we keep it to ourselves, or do we tell?"  Of course, we tell.  We're too afraid not to.

Posts.Title: So I am riding the ANXIETY Bus right now... Fitztwins

Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2012 01:29PM amontro wrote: Diagnosed almost 4 years ago - single mastectomy with mets to my spine and lung.  Herceptin and arimidex treatment beginning 3 1/2 years ago.  I was told that my disease was very aggressive and that it would spread quickly.  I was told to go out and buy a wig and prepare for the worst.  At the time, I bought a very expensive wig at $300 and it's still sitting in a box under my bed.  After the initial diagnosis, my onc kept telling me to do things, like travel, while I still can because quality of life is very important.
Posts.Title: Expected Life SPAMgirl jocanuck1951

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2014 09:48PM amontro wrote: I often have to take a break from going on this web site because it does break my heart to read about the young women with small and teenage children that they are dealing with. I post when I can to agree or add to a comment, but I feel that the younger ones may think I have nothing to add to having come this far in years. I'm 72, Stage IV from the start in 2008, still working to pay the bills and to be able to afford things that I would do without otherwise. I am paying for the AARP supplement which works for me because I have no copays, so far. Chrissy, I agree with you that, when the time comes, I'm going to call it quits, too. I can't see myself lingering on and in pain do to treatments. It will only make my family suffer.  I'm not going to be a burden. I have more side effects due to the meds I'm taking and I'm coping with that.  There are days when I am in so much pain that only percocet gets me through.  Effexor helps me manage my depression, and ativan  with my anxiety. I can't come on this website very often because I use the computer at work.  If and when I retire I will have no use of a computer.  I suppose I will be in the company of a lot of people my age who either don't have a computer, or don't know how to use one.
Posts.Title: Over 60 and Over 70 threads. Crone Crone

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2012 12:32PM amontro wrote: Wait until your employer gets a chance to see how well you perform before you tell them anything, and don't tell them everything. They just need to know that you're having non-specific  medical treatments. If it's a real concern, don't forget to tell them that you will work through your lunch hour on the day that you will be late. If you can, you can also make up some of the time at the end of the day, e.g., if you lose an hour, work 15 minutes later each day for a week.
Posts.Title: Starting a new job-- how to tell my new employer about my health QueenOfHope texasrose361

Posts.Content: amontro wrote: I'm at work right now and I'll be leaving, but I need something to say tomorrow to this: My supervisor just came over to  me and told me to "wipe down" the board room. It's just been painted and the table needs wiping down and so do the chairs and the backs of the chairs.  By the way, the shelves, too. I told him that I have cancer in my spine and I also have a crack in my spine. So he tells me to just wipe down the surfaces - just what I can reach at arm's height and length. So I tell him again that I have cancer in my spine and a crack... He then tells me to think about it and if I can do it let him know. I said that I can't, I have cancer in my spine, etc.  He says "Let me know". Reporting him would be too over the top.  I'm just planning on ignoring him and when he asks, I'll just repeat "I have cancer, etc." See ya in the morning! Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2011 10:26AM amontro wrote: Thank you for the confirmation. While I still  have my energy, I'm going to have to make life altering changes.  I'm going to see a psychologist that my oncologist recommended.  My boy friend of 17 yrs (we've lived together for 14) is much younger than me and is having trouble accepting that the end is near. He's at the point where he's had true illnesses and hospitalizations of his own and he likes to say that he's sicker than I am.  I'm going to have to move from a 3rd floor condo (walk up) to something smaller without him.  I have to do it now before I get worse and still have the energy.  I  hope this psychologist works out to help me with the breakup and moving.  Can you recommend where I can get help with making lifestyle changes, either on this board or elsewhere?  Thank you so much for your honest responses.
Posts.Title: Stage IV-Can you go into remission, or be cured? amontro Landerson3237

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2011 01:25PM amontro wrote: Blondie - He's much younger than me and I spend more time taking care of him. I don't want to be fussed over, but when I'm not feeling well, he pushes me to take him shopping, fever and all. When he's sick, I have to wait on him hand and foot.  He doesn't like to hear me say that I don't feel good (I don't say it that often), and I can never say that I have cancer, he yells at me to cut that out.  He's totally in denial about my diagnosis and, unless I can convince him to attend couples therapy, I'd rather live alone than be pushed around.
Posts.Title: Stage IV-Can you go into remission, or be cured? amontro Landerson3237

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2014 04:16PM amontro wrote: Ask  her if you can accompany her on one of her visits.  Every once in while, my daughter will drive me to my appointment and join me and my doctor.  I think she wants to  make sure I'm not forgetting to tell the onc anything and, also to  hear what the onc has to say.
Posts.Title: Please! Help me help my Stage IV Mom! nicreit bhd1

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2013 06:05AM amontro wrote: I should have clarified. I don't feel more pain when I'm doing my regular duties on the computer - researching, entering, typing. My HR and supervisor get my oncologist's letter twice a year telling them of my restrictions. HR and the supervisor's boss (the owner) are aware and empathetic. I just don't want to blow the horn on the super. I'd rather not discuss the limitations of my conditions because then we open a can of worms about my job. I'm 70 and I won't make it financially without a full time job, especially a well paying, physically able one like this.  Percs help me through the day, so I can remain cheerful and productive. I thought I'd get more support here, but you're right - I'll just say "No!"
Posts.Title: What don't you understand about cancer? amontro amontro

Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2013 04:30PM amontro wrote: chefmiche - I've often wondered the same thing. I believe I am hanging on for my loved ones, but I hate it. I'm still working at 71 and I'll probably retire when I'm too sick to enjoy it. I try to use the money to travel to somewhere once a year and that's all that keeps me going. I wonder what would happen if I give in and stop the meds. I agree with you, I would need the pain meds.  I also don't want to be a burden on my family.  I guess that's what really keeps me going. As for depression, I have an appointment with an onc therapist on Thursday. I saw her in 2008 when I was first dx for a few times.  Last year I saw a onc psychologist for a few weeks.  As discussed on other threads, even though I'm Stage IV, they all say I seem be doing quite well. My looks, my attitude, my ability to work, etc. It's all b**ls**t!  I'm so unhappy. If quitting the meds would make me go faster, I'd stop in a heartbeat. My loved ones don't reach out to me even when I'm not feeling well.  I guess it makes them uncomfortable. Now that I've said my 2 cents, I will look forward to my therapy session in two days.
Posts.Title: What is the point of going through this.. chefmiche Jill49

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2014 04:25PM amontro wrote: I'm a hand person. I'm not a wimp about needles, but any where (including hospital, cardiologist's office) I've been for a blood draw can't find a vein.  My wrist my foot, my forearm - and then it gets painful. It turns out that I had my blood taken by a woman in Quest and a woman in my onc's office who just stuck the needle in painlessly and I was all set. My PowerPort has been in since 2008. It is hardly noticeable and I don't pay attention to it.  I use it for my treatments,  CT scans and any place who will use it except, of course, the blood drawers.
Posts.Title: Need a new IV location - suggestions?? JeninMichigan bhd1

Posts.Content: Jun 9, 2015 08:36PM amontro wrote: Hi, Pearlady! When I was diagnosed in 2008, Stage IV from the start, I was put on Herceptin, arimidex and zometa.  I'm still on those three.  Recently,  I was off the zometa for a few months when I thought I was going to have oral surgery, but since I've been back on it, my aches and pains are back, too.  Onc says zometa is for my bone/spine mets (I also have lung mets). I used to be a health nut before dx - no carbs, working out, etc.  Now, I pretty much eat what I want and have a sweet tooth, which I never had before. After menopause, I gained weight to the tune of 5 lbs. a year even though I watched what I ate and exercised.  Now, I don't gain weight, but I don't gorge myself either. My favorite pain killer is Percocet.  Unlike a lot of people, it does not make me tired.  It gives me energy. I am more alert with perc, so I take it in the morning, before lunch, and before I go home. My work requires Internet research and I am able to concentrate better. Pearlady, you seem to be dealing with this for quite a while. I wish you all the best. My mind wants to be 30-50, but my body tells me that I'm an old lady!
Posts.Title: How long have you been Stage IV? goldie0827 dormouse

Posts.Content: Oct 23, 2013 06:57AM amontro wrote: I should also add that it takes a while for the reconstruction to feel like it's a part of your body. I had a single mx. Up until a year after the surgery, I was aware of my new body part but after that I don't feel it any different than my real one. My skin has feelings and I think I have phantom "limb" because my nipple itches just like the real one. I hope this is encouraging because I had a radical mx and a lot of lymph nodes removed. That side of my chest was really caved in. Fujiimama, I love swimming and the foobs were a pain. When the swimsuit floated away from my body, there was a gap, and you could see the chest, or lack of. I bought a "swim" foob which cost quite a bit and there was no difference than an everyday one.
Posts.Title: Reconstruction @Stage IV fujiimama fujiimama

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2011 04:41PM amontro wrote: I was diagnosed early September 2008. Single mastectomy early October. Stage IV with spine and  3 lung mets.  Since December 2008, I've been on Herceptin, Arimidex and Zometa.  A few months later one of my lung mets disappeared and the others got just a little smaller. I remain the same to this day. I'm an old gal, still working (can't retire - have to pay the bills), some side effects, no hair loss and people tell me how great I look - and I hate pink cancer stuff, especially pinktober.
Posts.Title: How long since your stage 4 diagnosis? Iwillwinthisbattle harvey

Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2014 05:45AM amontro wrote: When it happens, hold a seance and let me know.
Posts.Title: New article about the breast cancer vaccine by 1/1/2020 MusicLover MusicLover

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2013 04:28PM amontro wrote: I've been on Ativan for years. I couldn't take it during the day because it made me sleepy, so I took it at night. I started seeing psychiatrist. One product didn't work for me. Then I was prescribed Brand A in small doses, building up to a larger one with 1/2 Ativans on the side. The Px added 1/2 Brand B only at night in addition to Bramd A. This stuff takes forever to have any affect. I'm still waiting for the full power of Brand A and Brand B to kick in. So now I'm down to 3 Brand A, 1/4 Brand B and Ativan 1 hr. apart at bedtime. All of this took about 4 months. I don't recommend your following this course unless it's right for you. I'm just saying that anything you go on will take time and patience, especially if you don't want to be sleepy during the day.
Posts.Title: Anxiety meds Lauriesh Rosevalley

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2014 03:05AM amontro wrote: Let me start by letting you know that I'm terrible at remembering anecdotes.  I read a long time ago that someone asked how you wanted to be remembered at your funeral.  Do you want them to say "It's too bad she died, but she kept a clean house." I got the shame from my mother who never wanted to have visitors at our home.  When I got married and had children, I didn't want people over either because nothing was as neat or clean at it "should be".  If I had to do it all over again, I'd still let the little ones strew their toys and be happy I was there for them instead of yelling at them not to make a mess. They're fine adults now and will help if necessary. I seldom ask for help because I don't want them to remember me for cleaning my home.  It's not as neat as I'd like, but, hey, I have cancer.
Posts.Title: Anger Over Friend's Comment on House Cleanliness JHeart carpe_diem

Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2013 07:08AM amontro wrote: Being diagnosed 5 yrs ago (one side)at stage IV, I had to wait 2 yrs. for reconstruction. I'm glad I did. I did not like the plastic surgeon recommended to me by my surgeon for many reasons. However, I feel "normal", as if it's a part of me. I hated wearing a foob When I took it off at night, I hated the sunken part of my chest as a reminder of my disease.
Posts.Title: Reconstruction @Stage IV fujiimama fujiimama

Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2014 03:34PM amontro wrote: I've been thinking of this, too. I started out 6 years ago with Stage IV, and I've remained the same since. My onc encouraged me to continue working and I have, but with less hours. I'm sure if I stayed home, I would be a couch potato (no disparagement about this), because I feel so awful every day. I go to work, stimulated with Percocet, but it gives me some purpose. As blondie alluded to, at least I am able to afford a vacation once in a while. I have that to look forward to. Recently, a lightbulb went off. My grandson has begun college and we talk more often than I ever imagined we would about his plans. Then I realized that perhaps I could help cultivate him in a non-interfering way.  I started thinking about having him join my SO and me for trips we could take with him.  Then I put the reins on. I could do this if I spend some of my savings,  or I could save better and last longer. Anyway, for a short while I believed my purpose was to help my grandson.  Only the near future will tell. Good luck to all of us. I hope we find what we need.
Posts.Title: Finding purpose raro raro

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2015 04:56PM amontro wrote: I learned in college that statistics lie, or at least you can make statistics come out any way you want. I've been Stage IV at the start since 2008. There are others who, unfortunately, don't get that kind of time. As many of us said, you must take one day at a time and don't fret about the future. Prepare for the worst, but hope for the best.
Posts.Title: 15 -20% 5 year survival rate..huh? LeeLee38 JeninMichigan

Posts.Content: amontro wrote: My newest ongoing meds are Effexor and Remiron for the last four months. Remiron dose is less than 2 grams. However, I am taking 225 mg. of Effexor in the morning. The muscles in my entire body, except my head, are hurting to the point that sometimes it's hard to walk. This has been getting worse for sometime. Last month, my psychiatrist didn't think anything of it, but now the pains are worse. Besides taking percocet for it, sometimes the pain goes away on its own. I searched for Effexor side effects and "serotonin syndrome" came up. I'll be seiing this dr. in two weeks. I am doing so well with Effexor that I'm almost afraid he'll start me on something else. Anyone else have this problem or similar? Thank you. Dx 9/2008, Stage IV, Grade 3, mets, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Excruciating muscle pain from Effexor? amontro chris1959

Posts.Content: Dec 5, 2012 11:10AM amontro wrote: stormynyte - I just got around to reading your post about your fil using vinegar and baking soda for his skin cancer. I've used a vinegar and baking soda mixture for years to clean my pipes (not my body or physically!), in the kitchen, bathtub and sink drains. Not sure if it works, but it's supposed to be a natural unclogger, lol.
Posts.Title: Lets do a Sh*t People say to Metastatic BC Patients Fitztwins ChicagoGirl

Posts.Content: May 27, 2014 09:23PM amontro wrote: I was supposed to die 5 years ago, but here I am.  People are just so used to  having me around that they probably don't think I have cancer anymore.    How about this scenario: They ask "How are you?"  Instead of saying "Fine", say "Lousy".  They will say "What's wrong?" You say " I've been hurting all afternoon." They'll say "Why?" You'll say "My cancer 's bothering me."  They'll say "Oh. Are you taking anything for it?" Now, what you want to say is "I'M F****ING DYING AND IT HURTS ALL THE TIME!". " I have a tube in my chest where they periodically pump poison, and I go for tests where they pump more poison into me",  but you don't say it because you're too nice. By the way, "Have a nice day."
Posts.Title: Lets do a Sh*t People say to Metastatic BC Patients Fitztwins ChicagoGirl

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2014 04:12PM amontro wrote: It could be that worrying about not worrying is a challenge unto itself. For many years, I ate right and took the right vitamins and supplements, low carbs, etc. I rarely ate sweets.  Since I began at the start with Stage IV, I decided that I'll do as I please.  I keep an eye on weight but for some reason, I have cravings for sweets.  I eat ice cream candy, cakes, pies and I know that this is supposed to be bad for cancer patients. It's been 5 years and no changes to the mets.  Can it be because I don't agonize over whether or not I should eat or not eat something? I am on so many prescriptions that I believe they nullify the good things I've taken into my body. As for pain, percocets are my friends. Everyone has their own path to do what your think is right for you, but stop and smell the roses.
Posts.Title: Curing the Incurable by Dr. William Donald Kelley MusicLover exbrnxgrl

Posts.Content: May 27, 2014 03:25PM amontro wrote: Before BC, nothing.  After BC, you name it, I tried it. I start out with Effexor in the morning, then I take one ativan 2x (an hour apart) before I go to bed.  At bedtime, I take a small dose of remeron which helps me sleep like a baby, but I can still wake up if I need to.
Posts.Title: Anti-depressants & Anti-Anxiety Meds & What Works For You DivineMrsM AmyQ

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2014 03:43PM amontro wrote: That train stops by my place every morning, too. I guess it's a side effect of Arimidex.  I also keep pills at my bedside to take when the alarm goes off. Percocet and aspirin. Then cereal and tea for breakfast, watch the local news, then shower. I give myself more time before I leave. Lately, by the time I get to work, I need another Percocet.  Perc helps me focus and gives me a little brighter outlook. Late afternoon, another perc. At home later on, one more.  Sometimes the pain is so insufferable that the pain meds don't work. Every bone/muscle in my body is affected.  I hope you find something that works most of the time. Bless you.
Posts.Title: Hit by a Train AmyQ AmyQ

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2014 08:59AM amontro wrote: Music, this is old news.  Pepsi and other sodas contain benzo-something or other which is poisonous.  Then again, so are most of our treatments.  Also, drinking soda water or seltzer is not bad for you.  There are no calories, sodium, or colorings.  It's just carbonated water. If you're happy with your raw food diet, keep going.  Your body knows whats best for you.
Posts.Title: News flash: Pepsi & other colas are cancer causing? MusicLover MusicLover

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2013 04:40PM amontro wrote: December 2008 until present:  herceptin, arimidex and zometa.  that's a long time, but the tumors have not grown. They've stayed the same size.  Plenty of side effectws, but no talk of stopping or changing meds. Should I be worried?
Posts.Title: Curious, how many of you have gotten 2+ years on a drug, Fitztwins SAMayoFL

Posts.Content: Jul 28, 2015 09:10PM amontro wrote: I had a lateral mastectomy 6 1/2 years ago, and after being stable for three years, I received an implant. During the time from the mx to the implant, I felt like a had a big hole in my chest. The prosthesis prescribed for me was heavy and I was devastated at the end of the day after I took it off. It made a loud thump when I threw it onto the chair. The cosmetic surgeon I had was no prize. I did not get what he should have given me, but (at my age), I was so happy to have something that makes me almost feel whole. I just can't look at it, because the cs was a jerk. My two cents.

Posts.Title: Will I die from MBC? diana50 Heidihill

Posts.Content: amontro wrote: I've vented in the past and so have many of you, so it's time to bring it up again.  I've been crabby this week and part of it has to do with not getting my meds in time from my psychiatrist's office. The staff will not allow me to call in a week or even a few days ahead of time because "it's too soon".  So, I called last Tuesday, 2 days before I'm due for a refill. The response was that the message would be given to the doctor. I took my last pill (I'm supposed to take 3) on Thursday. then I called the office again on Friday again "to give the message to the doctor".  I called Friday afternoon to speak with the office manager (as my psx requested I do when I'm not satisfied with the staff).  She said she had the request for my meds on a pile in front of her and would call my pharmacy that afternoon. Tuesday I was contacted by the pharm and when I picked up the meds, there were only 18 in the bottle.  I'm suposed to get 90 (3x a day). The pharm tech told me that my pharm did  not run out of pills, and the doctor requested that I only get 18.  That's unbelievable because he knows I'm doing so well with my meds. I'll be seeing him Thursday and he'll hear it from me.  How about you guys?  Any incompetence from your medical staffs? Dx 9/2008, Stage IV, Grade 3, mets, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: need to vent about medical office staff amontro amontro

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2014 04:03PM amontro wrote: The drug is Effexor and the psychiatrist is delighted that it has been working for so many months so far. It is the office staff that have always been the problem.  I'm happy with the doctor and happy with the meds, it's the staff that's driving me up a wall. In the past ten years  I've had problems with the staff for myself (with other therapists) and other members of the family. Of course, the staff have changed throughout the years and there must be something wrong with their training procedures.  Also, complaining to the docs and therapists does not work. Don't you think that any medical office personnel should be taught to be compassionate about patients?  Sure, there are patient pests, but those of us with cancer and mental challenges don't need their crap. There I've said it.  I've gotten out of my system for now. Thanks for reading.
Posts.Title: need to vent about medical office staff amontro amontro

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2014 11:47AM amontro wrote: Update - I saw the psychiatrist yesterday and after telling him my frustrating story, he told me he was leaving this particular practice and would have an office at least 35 miles away (it's more than that).  I've been assigned to a nurse practicioner to follow up on my meds,etc., but my current psych told me he's giving me refills with my scrip, so I can deal with it ahead of time. Boo!

Posts.Content: Sep 9, 2013 09:36PM amontro wrote: Jill, your comment at your book signing reminds me of last year when my adult children threw me a surprise 70th  birthday party.  There were so many relatives, some I haven't seen in ages, and I thought "Gee, now I know who's going to show up at my funeral".
Posts.Title: Gallows/Black Humor Nel surfdreams

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2015 09:48PM amontro wrote: Stage IV from the start - early October 2008.  My oncologist told me to get my affairs in order and to plan any trips I'd like to make. She said my cancer was aggressive and would spread quickly.  When my surgeon came out of surgery for my single mastectomy, she looked at my daughter, lowered her head, and shook it sideways (no). Mets are to lungs and spine and still are. Started and ended radiation last two weeks of November 2008.  Started Herceptin and arimidex December 2008. Still alive and sometimes kickin'.  Still working at 73, so that I can feed my wanderlust once a year (couldn't afford last year, though).  Employers were wonderful enough to give me a sit-down job doing research and admin duties.  Still dealing with side effects, which have slowed me down from the active person I used to be. My heart goes out to those Stage IV who are young and to those who have young children.  You are in my thoughts often.

Even when I have time off, I don't have the means or the money or physicality to do much of anything.

I started a few months ago because I had many problems with my recon and I found support and information that helped me tremendously. So now I read as many threads as I can that apply not only to my Stage IV situation but other areas that will help me . I know my treatments will progressively make me feel worse, but at least I have a place to go to for understanding,support and, yes, even sympathy. Thank you.
Posts.Title: Please share how breastcancer.org has impacted you.... Moderators BouncingBetties

Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2011 04:08PM amontro wrote: You're all not going to like this, but the only thing that keeps mosquitos and no-see-ums away is Ben's 100% deet.  I've used it for almost 15 years.  I started when I visited an island where I got bitten incessantly and the bites got infected.  Still worked last visit and at home. Ben's 100% comes in a small orange pump bottle.  Spray it on and spread with your hand. Don't use it on your face, just the proximity of the stuff repels the little beasts.Be careful because it eats fingernail polish. I use it before I leave the house and, when I do, I don't get bitten.  Island is still on my bucket list.
Posts.Title: Preventing mosquito bites? moogie BeckySharp

Posts.Content: Sep 6, 2013 04:39PM amontro wrote: Sorry it took me so long to reply, but I do n ot always have access to a computer. 1. My employers are very good people.  I have been given the task of being an administrative assistant and receptionist.  I can use my brain, and I can sit. I am allowed the time off that I need for appointments and tests.  I need the income because I do not have much in savings and retirment. I also have great co-workers so that I like to go to work.  If I could retire tomorrow I probably wouldn't because I may turn lazy! 2. Some of my side effects are under control, but there's alway a new medication with its challenges. I see doctors a few times a week so even my free time is busy. Aside from my onc, my other specialists always have something new for me to try. 3. My support system consists of my significant other and my adult children. My onc suggested I stop living with my SO because of the stress (his medical problems), so we are living apart and I visit a few times a week. My oldest daughter is on hand if I need help or rides. My son always calls, and my youngest daughter is dealing with bi-polar, so I don't bring up my stuff with her.  She is not able to handle it. 4. I started out not smiling. I'm unhappy because my journey is going to take longer than I thought. After 4 1/2 yrs I'm doing ok, but when my numbers change I know I'll be in for a long, slow fight.  For the last few months, my psychiatrist has been trying different medication to keep a smile on my face.  So far, we haven't found the right meds.  Also, this board does a lot to strengthen me when I read the thoughts of the other Stage IVs. 5. I live in Fairfield county Connecticut.  I've always lived in this area. It's a town but near parks. We are close to NYC and I enjoy going in when I can. I rent a condo. 6. "Are you afraid?"
Posts.Title: 5-Questions: amontro susan_02143 texasrose361

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2013 03:09PM - edited Sep 10, 2013 03:10PM by amontro I've done some planning myself. When I was dx w/Stage IV almost 5 yrs ago, I updated my will, sold my condo "as is", and live in a rented a condo since  last year. I wanted to be buried with one of my relatives and the person who met the criteria was my grandfather who died in 1927.  The only glitch is that I have to be cremated to be buried with him. My daughter is a devout catholic and doesn't like cremation, but the church allows it if you'll be buried in a cathoic cemetery and not sit on a mantle, or scattered to the 4 winds. What I saying is that my family will be the ones who attend my funeral and come to visit my grave.  I had my daughter's input when I picked out the stone for my grave. Grandpa did not have one so his name is first his 3 yr old baby who died same year is second, and my name is third.  My DD wanted crosses in the corners. When I am ready to preplan the funeral I will, again, have my DD's input. She will be the one who will be there. My son and other daughter will find the closure in the ceremony that they've been through with other relatives. I'm trying to save my family money by doing these things ahead of timethen they can just show up. I'm still at loose ends as to what my obituary is going to say - either a lot, or just a one liner. P.S. I need another update for my will and don't feel like spending $3-500.
Posts.Title: But wait, I'm not packed!!! JillThut jocanuck1951

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2013 03:37PM amontro wrote: Regrets are a two edged sword. If you had not lived your life as you did, everything would have been changed and you may not have had the same experiences. I've always thought I should save more money for retirement.  Then I've thought suppose I die sooner than retirement?  So, here I am with very little retirement money, but a lot of memories of how I spent my money for enjoyment. I'm still working at 71 so I can have extra money to buy what I want.  There will be enough time to frugal when I have to quit - and i will have to quit when my Stage IV progresses, and it will.
Posts.Title: Leaving Regret Behind Brendatrue Romansma

Posts.Content: May 4, 2015 03:35PM amontro wrote: Ever since my diagnosis and treatments (being on and off of drugs that cause diarrhea and/or constipation), I started using extra long panty liners, the ones with wings. Since they extend to the rear of the panties, there is coverage for some leakage. They've been a blessing while I'm at work and they have caught small accidents. I particularly use Always Infinity Overnight Longs with wings. They are extra long so don't place them too far in front, they'll extend to the back, and the wings keep them in place.  Also, the back of the liner is wider.

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2014 02:36PM amontro wrote: Before the cancer, I absolutely would not take pills.  I used natural remedies. Now, I am relying on meds to feel good.  Right now I'm on Effexor daily, and Ativan, as needed.  Besides pain killing, percocet puts me in a pleasant frame of mind.
Posts.Title: "as-needed" happy pill? kebab Loveforlife

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2013 02:27PM amontro wrote: Stage IV for over 4 years - still working at age 70 - attribute aches and pains to side effects from meds, treatment, etc.  When I get home from work I'm too tired to enjoy life. I do enjoy snuggling with my wooby blanket and watching shows that I've dvr'd. What's scaring the hell out of me is when is it all going to catch up?  I know one of these days I will go into a downward spiral and get worse day to day - Because I know it will never get any better.
